controls.title: Ensure message of the day is configured properly
controls.description: The contents of the /etc/motd file are displayed to users after login and are generally used to display a system-wide message.
controls.rationale: Warning messages inform users who are attempting to login to the system of their legal status regarding the system and must include the name of the organization that owns the system and any monitoring policies that are in place.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify that the contents match site policy:
# cat /etc/motd
Verify that the message does not contain \m, \r, \s, \v or references to the OS platform
controls.remediation: Edit the /etc/motd file with the appropriate contents according to your site policy, remove any instances of \m, \r, \s, or \v.
controls.references: 1. See the motd(5) man page for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
v7: 5.1 Establish Secure Configurations

controls.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/motd are configured
controls.description: The contents of the /etc/motd file are displayed to users after login and are generally used to display a system-wide message.
controls.rationale: If the /etc/motd file does not have the correct ownership it could be modified by unauthorized users with incorrect or misleading information.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify Uid and Gid are both 0/root and Access is 644:
# stat /etc/motd
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--) Uid: ( 0/ root) Gid: ( 0/ root)
controls.remediation:
Run the following commands to set permissions on /etc/motd:
# chown root:root /etc/motd
# chmod u-x,go-wx /etc/motd
controls.references: 1. See the motd(5) man page for more information.
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 3.3 Configure Data Access Control Lists
v7: 14.6 Protect Information through Access Control Lists
